metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of Original Defendant v. Legal Representatives of Original Plaintiff

facts.text: In 1921, the plaintiff executed in favour of the defendant an otti kuzhikanam deed in respect of the suit property. By this deed, the plaintiff sold to the defendant the building standing on the property for 350 fanams and also transferred to him for 350 fanams the right to possess and enjoy the property for 12 years in kuzhikanam right with liberty to plant coconut trees thereon, expressly reserving for the plaintiff the right to enjoy the fruit bearing trees then standing on the property. The deed provided that after the expiry of 12 years the defendant would on demand demolish and take away the building and surrender possession of the land on receipt of 350 fanams and the agreed compensation for the coconut trees planted by him.
The plaintiff instituted a suit for redemption of the property.
During the pendency of the litigation, the plaintiff and the defendant died, and their legal representatives were substituted in their place.
On May 31, 1951, the Principal District Munsif Quilon decreed the suit.
On appeal, the District Court of Quilon affirmed this decree.
The present appellant, who is one of the legal representatives of the original defendant, filed a second appeal in the High Court of Kerala (S.A. No. 852 of 1957).
During the pendency of this appeal, the Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1960 (Act IV of 1961) came into force.
The High Court of Kerala by judgment and decree dated July 25, 1961 negatived the appellant's contentions and dismissed the appeal.
The appellant appeals to this Court by special leave.
During the pendency of this appeal, Act IV of 1961 was repealed and the Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963 (Act 1 of 1964) came into force.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is a kuzhikanamdar within the meaning of s. 2(50)(i) r/w s. 2(22) and s. 2(50)(i) r/w s. 2(21) of Act IV of 1961, or s. 2(57)(d) r/w s. 2(28) of Act 1 of 1964, entitled to fixity of tenure and protection from eviction.
Whether the appellant is alternatively the holder of a kudiyiruppu within the meaning of s. 2(50)(i) r/w s. 2(21) of Act IV of 1961, or s. 2(57)(h) r/w s. 2(26) of Act 1 of 1964.
Whether the appellant was a kudikidappukaran entitled to protection from eviction.

petitioner_arguments.text: The appellant claimed fixity of tenure and protection from eviction on the ground that he was a kuzhikanamdar or alternatively, the holder of a kudiyiruppu, and, therefore, a tenant within the meaning of s. 2(50)(i) r/w s. 2(22) and s. 2(50)(i) r/w s. 2(21) of Act IV of 1961.

The appellant claims fixity of tenure and protection from eviction on the ground that he is a kuzhikanamdar within the meaning of s. 2(57)(d) r/w s. 2(28), or alternatively, the holder of a kudiyiruppu within the meaning of s. 2(57)(h) r/w s. 2(26) of Act 1 of 1964.

The words 'with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, for the enjoyment of those trees' are not essential parts of the definition of kuzhikanam in s. 2(28), and a transfer of land for the purpose of planting fruit-bearing trees thereon is kuzhikanam though there is no transfer of the fruit-bearing trees standing on the land at the time of the transfer and though the transfer is not for the enjoyment of those trees.

court_reasoning.text: The deed of 1921 was styled otti kuzhikanam deed. In Malabar, otti designates a possessory mortgage. Kuzhikanam means compensation allowed for the value of trees planted or other improvements made by the tenant or mortgagee on relinquishing possession. Under a kuzhikanam mortgage or lease, the grantee normally acquires the right to hold for 12 years for planting fruit-bearing trees and claim compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Had there been no special definition, the grantee under the deed of 1921 would be a kuzhikanamdar.

court_reasoning.text: s. 2(28) of Act 1 of 1964 defines kuzhikanam as a transfer of garden lands or other lands or both, with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, for the enjoyment of those trees and for the purpose of planting such fruit-bearing trees thereon but shall not include a usufructuary mortgage as defined in the Transfer of Property Act, 1882. This definition is both inclusive and exhaustive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unless the context requires otherwise, kuzhikanam in the Act has only this meaning.

court_reasoning.text: The deed of 1921 effected a transfer of land for planting coconut trees but expressly reserved for the grantor the right to enjoy the fruit-bearing trees then standing and did not transfer those trees to the grantee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: A transfer of land without the fruit-bearing trees then standing on it and not carrying the right to enjoy those trees is not kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2(28).

court_reasoning.text: The force of the words 'if any' is that if there are fruit-bearing trees on the land at transfer, the trees also must be transferred for enjoyment by the transferee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejects appellant's contention that the words are not essential.

court_reasoning.text: It is not the case of the plaintiff that the deed created a usufructuary mortgage under TPA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definition excludes such, but not applicable here.

court_reasoning.text: s. 2(26) defines kudiyiruppu as a holding or part consisting of the site of any residential building, sites of appurtenant buildings, necessary lands for convenient enjoyment and easements, but not including kudikidappu.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material on record to show the building is residential or land necessary for convenient enjoyment.

holdings.text: The contention that the deed of 1921 granted kuzhikanam rights as defined in s. 2(28) of Act 1 of 1964 is rejected.
The contention that the appellant is the holder of kudiyiruppu is rejected.
Section 13 of Act 1 of 1964 gives tenants fixity of tenure except as provided, but appellant is not a tenant as defined.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant claimed tenant status under these for fixity of tenure; High Court negatived

statutes_cited.name: Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963 (Act 1 of 1964)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines tenant including kuzhikanamdar and kudiyiruppu holder; s.13 gives fixity of tenure; court interpreted definitions to deny appellant status

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 2(28) of Act 1 of 1964 excludes it from kuzhikanam definition

outcome.summary: The appeal fails as the appellant is neither a kuzhikanamdar nor holder of kudiyiruppu under the relevant definitions in Kerala Land Reforms Act, 1963, and thus not entitled to fixity of tenure or protection from eviction. The decrees of the courts below stand affirmed.

key_quotes.text: "Kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2(28) means a transfer 1 of garden lands or of other lands or of both, 2 with the fruit-bearing trees, if any, standing thereon at the time of the transfer, 3 for the enjoyment of those trees and 4 for the purpose of planting such fruit-bearing trees thereon."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation leading to rejection of kuzhikanam claim

key_quotes.text: "A transfer of land without the fruit-bearing trees then standing on it and not carrying with it the right to enjoy those trees is not a kuzhikanam as defined in s. 2(28)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly applies definition to facts of deed, deciding key issue
